text: I want to share some thoughts I've been sitting with for a while now.
I keep hearing AI this, AI that. But what we're actually using are language models. Pattern matchers trained on text. Calling it AI sets wrong expectations.
When I first started using these tools, I blamed myself when things went wrong. Bad prompt, I thought. Try harder. Sound familiar?
LinkedIn is full of people claiming ten x productivity. But have you noticed nobody shows the debugging sessions? The reverts? The rewrites?
So I looked at actual research. Turns out developers feel faster but measure slower. And most companies have already had production issues from generated code.
Here's what I realized. I wasn't saving time. I was just moving the work from typing to reading and fixing. Different effort, same hours.
The trust problem hit me hard. I'd use the output but then spend ages verifying it. What's the point if I don't trust what it gives me?
Security data scared me. The models learned from Stack Overflow and GitHub, good and bad code alike. No filter for vulnerabilities.
The context problem is maddening. Every session, I start over. Explain the project again. Watch it forget what I told it ten minutes ago.
Programming languages exist because English is imprecise. Why are we going backwards? Determinism matters in engineering.
I think many of us feel this but don't say it. Fear of looking outdated. Fear of missing out. It's okay to be critical.
And let's talk about the business model. Trained on our code, sold back to us. No warranty. No refunds when it wastes hours.
I'm not saying abandon these tools. I'm saying use them differently. With constraints. With skepticism. With explicit approval gates.
So I built something. A framework that adds structure. Not magic, just discipline.
The core idea is simple. Keep humans in control. Add structure to reduce chaos. Make context persist across sessions.
It's two layers. A shared base everyone uses. A project layer you customize. Override what doesn't fit.
Instead of just asking for code, you explore first. Then plan. Then wait for approval. Then implement. Forced discipline.
Different modes for different jobs. Exploration mode can't write files. Developer mode can't do massive refactors. Constraints prevent disasters.
Approval gates are explicit. The model asks, you say yes or no. Silence isn't consent. Questions aren't approval. Clear rules.
Context files persist between sessions. Your tech stack, your patterns, your decisions. No more re-explaining from scratch.
Domains capture your standards. How you write TypeScript, how you test, how you handle errors. Written rules the model can follow.
Works with whatever tool you use. Claude, Cursor, Copilot. Same constraints apply everywhere.
I want to be clear about what this doesn't do. It won't make language models reliable. They're still probabilistic. This is about managing that reality.
What it does is make the chaos manageable. Easier to review. Harder to go off track. Teams stay consistent.
I've learned when these tools help and when they hurt. Boilerplate, yes. Novel design, no. Test scaffolding, yes. Security logic, no.
Your intuition as an engineer comes from years of mistakes. A model can't give you that. The craft is still yours.
Setup takes five minutes. Clone the repo, link to your project, run one command.
My ask is simple. Be honest about what works and what doesn't. Add guardrails. Stay in control. Pragmatism over hype.
If this resonates, check out the repo. If it doesn't, that's fine too. At least we're having an honest conversation.
Research links are in the repo if you want to dig deeper.
